headline: Cajun Crawfish and Shrimp Étouffée
description: An authentic Louisiana recipe with a rich and spicy fresh tomato based roux with fresh garlic, bell peppers, celery and onions mixed with crawfish and shrimp. A little time consuming but well worth it!! Serve over steamed rice with hushpuppies and/or crackers on the side.

video.description: An authentic Louisiana recipe for spicy Cajun stew.
video.name: Cajun Crawfish and Shrimp Etouffe

name: Cajun Crawfish and Shrimp Étouffée
recipeIngredient: 1 pound medium shrimp, peeled and deveined

recipeInstructions.text: Heat the oil in a heavy skillet over medium heat. Gradually stir in flour, and stir constantly until the mixture turns 'peanut butter' brown or darker, at least 15 or 20 minutes. I use a large fork with the flat side to the bottom of the pan in a side to side motion. This is your base sauce or 'roux'. It is very important to stir this constantly. If by chance the roux burns, discard and start over.

Once the roux is browned, add the onions, garlic, celery and bell pepper to the skillet, and saute for about 5 minutes to soften. Stir in the chopped tomatoes and fish stock, and season with the seafood seasoning. Reduce heat to low, and simmer for about 20 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Season the sauce with hot pepper sauce and cayenne pepper (if using), and add the crawfish and shrimp. Cook for about 10 minutes, or until the shrimp are opaque.

review.reviewBody: This dish was a hit at our house! We like a lot of spice so we used hot cajun seasoning, hot sauce and cayenne. I used bacon grease instead of oil and it really added a lot of flavor. I cooked the roux until a little past peanut butter brown color. It turned out perfectly! I also added diced smoked sausage to the pan with the onion, garlic and bell pepper. I substituted canned tomatoes and chicken stock because that's what I had in the pantry. Overall, this is a great dish that's easy to prepare and tastes delicious!
Awesome
It turned out really good. It took me a little longer because I tripled the recipe. It taste like my Cajun friends moms Etouffee. I would recommend this recipe.

IN Louisiana, basically a very good dish. Butter is better than oil. Bacon drippings best of all. You can do without the cayenne. Let the individuals spice it up on their own as they see fit. Otherwise, everything in it is very good.

What I love about this recipe is that the roux is easy to make and deepens the flavor of the etouffe, for a truly authentic taste. It's the better etouffe recipe on this site. TIP: The recipe is perfect as written, but I also make it with an extra tomato added OR 1 tomato and 1 can of stewed or diced tomatos. The recipe is really flexible, so you if you like tomato flavor, sometimes I even add a 1/2 cup or 4 oz. can of tomato sauce. It tastes amazing as long as you get the roux proportion right! :) I also like green onions, so I top it with a T of chopped green onions like I do my baked potatoes. Delicious! My family always asks for seconds!

The basic recipe is a great start. I did wonder about the absence of herbs and added Italian mix (oregano, basil, thyme, rosemary), a bit of additional thyme, parsley, and a bay leaf. I used fresh shrimp and made a quick broth from the shells to sub for fish stock. I don’t know what “seafood seasoning” is. If it’s Old Bay I’ll I pass. I added Creole seasoning, and skipped adding the cayenne and hot sauce. It turned out delicious.

Excellent - this is Cajun restaurant quality, it is soooo good! First we made the roux with veg oil and it smelled burned, we had to throw it out. Other reviews I read used butter instead, so tried that and it was perfect. Did not change anything else. Served over white rice of course. Can't wait to make this again!
My family absolutely loved this recipe. My husband just asked when were going to have it again. Great flavor!!!

Doubled the recipe and used only shrimp. Made my own shrimp stock from the shells. Cooked vegetables a bit longer than called for. Used olive oil. Added a squeeze of fresh lemon and some butter just at the finish. Absolutely one of the best recipes that I have made from this website. It was gone an hour after it was done. I don't have words to tell you how darn tasty this is.
SOME CHANGES, MIXED RUE TO A 5/50 MIX, USED A VEGETABLE STOCK INSTEAD
Never had this dish before. Left out the cayenne and made with only shrimp. This was delicious!

This is very good, but I learned from some excellent Cajun cooks to make the roux in the microwave. Just melt your butter and flour and stir, microwave for about three minute intervals until you get the color you want. It usually takes about nine minutes for a peanut butter color or a little longer for a darker roux. Use a large glass bowl to prevent an overflow. I have never had a burn using this method. When the roux is done, I mix in the vegetables and put in a pan on the stove top and proceed with the directions.

My best dish so far. I honestly never really season to what it calls for, I do my own thing but I used all the ingredients this recipe called for except using butter instead of oil for the flour. It made a huge difference.
I made this for my wife’s Mother’s Day dinner and she loved it! The only variation I made was pasta instead of rice, which I might say was pretty tasty!
Added crab and cut the shrimp in small pieces. Came out fabulous

Super good and worth the 20min roux stirring! Didn’t have crawfish and didn’t have fish stock so I used double shrimp and 1 cup of clam sauce. I was making for my kids to eat too, so I left out the cayenne. It still had a good amount of heat for my husband and me. Will make again - thanks for sharing the recipe!
Simple and so good!

great recipe. I dont like seafood but my husband does so since the recipe called for 1 lb of crawfish and 1 lb of shrimp I thought it would be perfect to substitute the shrimp for precooked diced chicken breast. so before I added the meats I separated it into two skillets and put crawfish in one and chicken in the other. it came out really good , better than I expected so I will definitely be making this again.

Turned out great, kids even liked it. Only bad thing there were no left overs for me! I used chicken broth vs fish stock, just what I had and used butter and oil for rue other than that followed everything else. One of those meals the more you ear the better it gets.
We made this Sunday with some left over crawfish we peeled. It was so delicious. Even my picky kiddo thoroughly enjoyed it. I highly recommend.
incredible recipe. excellent. i followed it exactly
This was delicious, I’m actually making it again tonight for company. Try lowering the heat for the first few steps, I had to add more fish stock the first time because it became too thick.
Love, love, love it! Used chicken broth, a can of diced tomatoes w/garlic & black pepper and only shrimp, but it was fantastic! Will be making it again and again.

Love this recipe. I have made it at least 5 times now. Making a grocery list now to make it again. The roux color is so important. I always go with a copper penny color. It makes it a rich flavor vs a floury taste. It will go from a light brown to burnt quick. It needs your full attention to keep stirring to achieve the color. Then quickly remove from burner or add the next ingredients quickly to stop the browning. Recipe as is... IS PERFECT! I like it spicy. This time instead of the cayenne pepper I'm going to try chipotle pepper.
Tasted wonderful all who shared loved it.
I've made this several times. It's awesome. Quick, simple, and yummy.
love it, love it, love it!!!
I did not make any changes in the recipe. Next time I may not add as much hot sauce. I will definitely make it again!

This recipe was excellent! Etoufee is one of my favorite creole dishes to eat, so I have to admit I was very intimidated to make it. But it turned out great! I didn’t change much of the recipe at all. Only thing I changed was using clam juice instead fish stock, used no crawfish only shrimp and used only a sprinkle of crawfish. This was excellent over rice and I will make it again and again!
This recipe is better than most of the seafood restaurants where I have tried etoufee
This was good and spicy. Sauce a bit thick and rich for us, but I’m sure just a matter a preference.

It was delicious! It seemed like 2 tbs of hot sauce would have been a little too hot for me so I cut it in half. I had to make other changes. We don't have crawfish anywhere near me so I went with 2 lbs of peeled shrimp and I also decide to cook the onions, celery, garlic and green pepper in oil first and then took them out and put them aside while I made the roux. I couldn't find fish stock so I used a 8 oz bottle of clam juice and that worked out fine. Once I had the sauce going I put in the diced tomatoes for 5 minutes and then added back in the onions, peppers, celery, garlic mixture and then added the peeled shrimp for 10 minutes until they turned pink. Served it over rice, but it would probably look better with a formed cup of rice in the center sprinkled with some cilantro or parsley.
I doubled the recipe, but didn't add cayenne and it was wonderful

In my notes I said pour a glass of wine first. When making the Roux it helps the time go by quickly. I cut this in half and it works out well. I also use red bell pepper because my husband doesn't like green and I can hide the red easier.
Good recipe.

It's a tasty dish, but that's a Creole recipe, not traditional Cajun. There are no tomatoes in Cajun etouffee (no tomatoes in Cajun jambalaya either :-). Also, if you're using fresh shrimp and pre-cooked crawfish (I live in NOLA and have never seen 'raw crawfish tail meat' for sale) they will be rubber after cooking for 10 mins. Taste them at 5 mins, and unless you live at high altitude, they'll be done.... Happy Cooking!!!

Oops, forgot to add... Make sure to get ALL the fat and juices out of the package of crawfish tails too. TONS of flavor in there!!
This was so easy to make and tasted delicious!! We can’t eat shrimp so we subbed it out for clams. Will definitely make this again. Tasted exactly like it should have
Great recipe! I didn't use shrimp but doubled the crawfish. Amazing!
Made this today and my family loved it. Thanks for sharing

Two things when making a proper roux: oil and flour should be in equal parts and “peanut butter” color is not dark enough... more like “chocolate”. Roux is not hard.... just keep stirring and keep an eye on it... when it starts to get hot enough, it can change color pretty quickly.

I used all crawfish again, but ran out of liquid shrimp boil (used before for seafood seasoning). Definitely needs that edge, but still full of flavor. I tried 2/3 oil and 1/3 butter for the roux, without much taste difference.
This was pretty good, but did not keep for long. After the sauce soaked into the rice it was no longer palatable.
My family LOVED this!!! I don’t typically take the time to review things, but this recipe (didn’t change a thing) was excellent. Served it over rice.

My husband was born and raised in New Orleans, he is always looking for authentic LA food. This hit the spot for him! Thank you so much for sharing! He has been asking me at least once a week to make this recipe, HA!
Absolutely amazing. I doubled the celery in it and added cayenne pepper. This is a family FAV!

I was a little skeptical because the recipe looks so easy. My wife and I both are completely shocked!! Our turned out just as good as some of the local Cajun joints. We will absolutely make this again!! Fantastic!!
Really good. I used the shrimp shells and made a shrimp stock instead of the fish stock.

This is definitely a keeper. The only thing I changed was to use butter instead of oil. We like things spicy so the recipe was perfect for us, but you could always tone down the spice and let people add more to their liking. Yum!

Hubby asked for Shrimp Etouffe and I naturally went to Allrecipes. This is a KEEPER! Easy to follow instructions and the result was delicious!!! I only modified a few things: chicken broth instead of fish stock, butter instead of oil, and all shrimp. Followed directions exactly and the result was amazing.
We only had Blackened Old Bay so we used that and did not add any hot sauce or red pepper. I did add more stock at the end so it would pour over rice better. Awesome!!
I made the recipe just as it was written and my picky eaters ate every bit. I’ll defi make this again, but will need to double the recipe.
Great recipe! Added Slap ya mama seasoning and it was Bon!
Great recipe. One of my favorite meals.
Followed directions according to the recipe and was not disappointed. I love anything cajun or creole and this really scratched that itch. Even my mother liked it (as she’s a very picky eater).
family favorite
This turned out amazing! I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil, but kept everything else the same. The flavors were popping! Super easy, one pot is all you need!

I just made it tonight. Wonderful recipe! For my personal taste I still think something is missing?? I didn't put any cayenne or hot sauce. Other reviewers warned me that it would be too hot. I like hot! And it was perfect without those two ingredients. I lived in Louisiana for five years and although it's not "required" I can't live without catfish with my etoufee (see picture with fish!) I didn't have any fish stock so I used chicken broth and helpful hint: I learned from a food blogger that you can simmer your peeled-off shrimp shells in water or other stock to turn it into "seafood stock"!

This etouffee is delicious! I wanted just crawfish so skipped the shrimp and served with yellow rice. It was really spicy so cut back significantly on the cayenne if you don't want a lot of heat. I cannot wait to make it again.
This was perfect as described. I used more stock and all shrimp. It was excellent and easy. Worth the 15 minutes to make the roux, be patient its worth it!

The author must be from the N. O. area. Cajuns don't normally use tomatoes of tomato products in their gumbos though there are about as many recipes as there are cajuns. The basic recipe is a 50% oil to flour mixture for the roux, the cajun trilogy (onions, bell pepper & celery), almost any combination of meat & seafood you can imagine, black pepper & salt and innumerable variations of herbs and spices. It is hard to mess up a gumbo if you get the roux right, it is the key to the recipe. Incidentally, the darker you can get the roux without burning it, the better the taste. Be very, very careful, however as it gets darker since the slightest bit of burned flour will taint the gumbo and there is no known remedy for that.
I made this tonight and it turned out awesome. Followed recipe exact without using hot sauce or cayenne due to 6 yr old eating as well. Delicious!!!

This recipe was excellent!! I always wanted to make shrimp étouffée and this was perfect!! I did use butter instead of vegetable oil, clam juice instead of fish stock, and Old Bay Seasoning as the seafood seasoning. I also made it solely with shrimp and not the crawfish tails. I served it with rice and we were in love. Will make again for sure. Thank you for the recipe!!

This is an ok recipe. I am from the heart of the Cajun Country. I will tell you, we use 1 stick of margarine / 2 pounds of seafood (ie: 1# Shrimp & 1# Crawfish or 1# Crab meat & 1# shrimp or 2#'s of crawfish, etc.), 1 can of Cream of golden mushroom soup, & 1 can of cream of celery or cream of shrimp. We also add the water to a good thickness. Not heavy and not thin. Chicken stock can be used also. Additionally, 1 cup of crawfish fat, if available. After all the seasoning, we do not use heavy amounts of cayenne because you do not want to over power the great seasonings of onion, bell pepper, celery, etc. Also add 2 tbl. spoon of tomato paste. We do not use fish stock. Reason, it doesn't stay long with the fish stock in it. We also do not use chopped tomatoes.

I made this recipe for the second time as of this review and for GOOD reason, it WORKS. Very flavorful and yummy, I just simply followed the directions and BAM it was awesome! I wish the rest of life worked this way lol.

This Etouffe is sooo good I had to make myself stop eating! The subtle changes I made was using crawfish tails I peeled that were leftover from a boil we had. I kept the tails and all the fat and seasoning, put into a Ziploc bag about half filled with water and froze it. When thawed I kept the seasoned water and used it for my stock. Ca c'est bon!

This is really good - made it using Bay Seasoning HOT and boy was it hot. Delete the cayenne if you use the hot variety of Bay. Found it was missing something initially and then noticed the recipes didn't call for salt - once I added that it was great.
Dish was a huge hit! Used leftover crawfish from a boil. Don't be intimated by the roux. Just keep stirring and everything comes together beautifully!

As the other reviewers indicated, use butter NOT oil to make the roux. I've made this twice. I found frozen crawfish at our local Walmart! Since fish stock is very hard to find in the upper midwest (and I'm not making it from scratch), I used one cup of "Better than Bullion" fish stock and the next time 1/2 cup of "better than Bullion" vegetable stock and 1/2 cup clam juice. Both options work very well.

Excellent recipe with a few changes. I had to add additional flour the second time I made it. Was good the first time, but it was a little too soupy following the recipe. I also used seafood broth for my liquid and I added creole seasoning and old bay seafood seasoning. Veggie I added red peppers and mushroom in addition to what was listed.
I downsize the servings until the amount of meat required was a little less than what I have. Used crawfish tails bought from Walmart freezer section. Did not use shrimp. Turned out great!
This was so yummy!!! Lots of flavor!! The only thing I did different was add 2 bay leaves and used a seafood stock instead of fish stock because was not able to find any in my local grocery store!

Opted to nix oil and use butter for roux & didn't have crawfish so I used shrimp and lobster. The rest of the recipe I kept the same. This dish was absolutely fun to make and not difficult at all. I loved it, had the perfect amount of spicy you would expect from a Cajun dish. If you are not a fan of spicy foods this is not for you. This will be going on my list to make again!!!
Didn't change a thing, it was excellent!!
YUM

We love creole/Cajun recipes and this one is excellent. Tasting it after adding the seafood(old bay) seasoning I thought it would be too salty but when served with rice, it came out perfect. I felt the heat was spot on with the amount of cayenne in the recipe but if you are not keen to spicy foods you will likely want to reduce it. Crayfish isn't readily available where I live so I opted for 2 lbs of shrimp. I do feel the cook times are a little off and reduced them slightly. I've made roux numerous times and it does take a while to get right. Overall it took about 30 minutes start to finish until the dish was served. I only have to kick myself that I forgot to get a loaf of crusty bread to go along with it.
I loved it. I thought the hot sauce and spice portions were too large and cut them back significantly; yet it was still to spicy for some in our family. Consider halving the seafood and hot sauce.

Yum! This was so good and so easy. The toughest part is chopping the vegetables. Making the roux was a snap -- you just have to stir constantly to keep it from burning like the directions say. I used 2# of medium-sized shrimp. It was so good! Thank you for a great recipe!

I give this recipe 4 stars because it's quick and easy to make, it tastes really good, the heat/spicyness is awesome. My family loved it. What sucked about it is it didn't look anything like the picture. I followed the recipe exactly. When the roux got to be a "peanut butter" brown it was still very runny and oily. So I took the suggestion of one of the reviews and cooked it a bit longer to a "milk chocolate " color, at which point it actually started to thicken up but was still quite runny. But then everything is a dark brown-the vegetables and seafood. Nothing was pretty or presentable about it. I will definitely make this again but next time I think I'll use butter instead of oil and see if that doesn't make a difference. Oh! I did make brown rice instead of white rice as we don't like white rice as well. Also, I couldn't find crawfish anywhere so I doubled up on the shrimp.

Love the flavors of this recipe. Only thing I will do next time is cut back on the old bay( that's what I used for seafood seasoning) and hot sauce. I don't like spicy at all and even without the cayenne pepper it was still to hot for me. Other than that this recipe is perfect!

Very good! I had to adapt this to what I had access to... using chicken and shrimp instead of crawfish and shrimp and chicken stock in place of fish stock. Very yummy!! I'll add this one to my meal rotation!
I was taught to always use equal portions of fat and flour when making roux, so I used 1/4 of each (but did need that extra bit of oil for sauteing my peppers and onion). I went with a dark brown roux, too.
Made with two pounds of crawfish tails. Otherwise prepared as stated. Absolutely fantastic.

Did add a couple more cups of clam juice and also a can of V8. I also added a small container of lump crab meat and about 1/2 lb garlic sausage. It was absolutely scrumptious. Spices were just right!! Will make again!!
This is a gumbo not etouffee, because you make a roux!! From a Louisiana Girl!

Delicious. I substituted some vegetable bouillon for fish stock and used olive oil for the roux. I did not use garlic. Did not have fresh crawdads, so resorted to using frozen cajun boiled crawfish from the grocery.

Made it again, kicked it up with the cayenne. Delicious.
Didn't have crawfish or fresh tomatoes so I doubled the shrimp and used canned tomatoes. Great taste. Time consuming though. About 60 minutes start to finish and almost all working time.

This was the first time for me to make a meal like this. It did take long, but glad to make it. I am not used to cajun food, so 2 tablespoons of seasoning was quite a bit much for my taste, but the rice helped out a lot. Next time I'll add more slowly for my liking. I did put just a little cayenne pepper in it and that was perfect. Thank you for sharing the recipe!
Delicious and easy to tweek according to your tastes
Delicious meal. I am in New England and crawfish are not readily available. Used lobster instead and it was fabulous!! Served on 7 grains and fresh baby kale.

This recipe is awesome! I will make it again. The hubby loved it over white rice. The only thing I changed was that I sautéed the onions, bell peppers, and celery in butter while the roux was cooking to get them soft because my husband does not like his vegetables to be crunchy. This recipe is a WIN.
I didn't add the cayenne and it was still a little too spicy for my taste. I poured it over rice and added sour cream when serving and it was amazing !
Super easy recipe that tasted complex. Flavors really developed layer after layer. Final product is impressive!
I replaced the crawfish with clam, and it still turned out pretty dang good! I approve!

This was my first experience making etoufee. It was excellent. I only used a dash of hot sauce and used a tablespoon of old bay. I did not add any of the cayenne pepper as my husband is ultra-sensitive to spicy food. I used a 15 oz can of diced, fire-roasted tomatoes since I did not have any fresh. We loved it!

I just used crawfish tails, and since they were already quite spicy I didn't need to add the hot sauce or the cayenne. Also didn't have fish stock and frankly didn't feel like making any, so I used chicken stock instead. The flavor was outstanding and there are no leftovers. Next time I will go out of my way to use fish stock and see how that changes the overall taste.

Absolutely wonderful recipe to jump off of. For the roux, I used 1 stick of butter because by eyeballing it, I didn't think 1/3 cup was enough. Cooked it to peanut butter color, whisking constantly so as not to burn it, and had zero problems. And that was my first time making roux! I had to omit the bell peppers because of a picky eater, so I just increased the onions to compensate. I also used a large can of medium-heat Rotel instead of the fresh tomatoes, and was so glad I did! I made the mistake of draining some of the liquid from the can, I won't do that next time because I had to then increase the amount of seafood stock to get the consistency right. And instead of the seafood seasoning, I used 1.5 tablespoons of "Slap Ya Mama" seasoning. Once it got close to the desired consistency (a little thinner), I added my 2 pounds of crawfish tails from our last crawfish boil, let it simmer about 10-15 minutes, and it was beautiful. It got a Ragin' Cajun's nod of approval (he had thirds ), and was hot enough for an East Texas country boy who loves his spicy food. For those who can't hardly handle pickled jalapeños for the heat level, SEASON CAREFULLY. This will be crazy hot for you... But for us Southerners, it's perfect. (Tip: I use the rice you steam in the bag in the microwave. So much easier.)
This recipe is almost like my mama's, and it smells like love, when it's cooking.

Excellent recipe, but I love reading all the ad libs from other cooks. I did the roux with half oil, half butter. Totally agree that it's not about time, but the color. Mine was a dark brown in 10 minutes. No crawfish at store, went with faux lobster. It was OK, but next time I'll skip. Used clam juice, but would like to make own fish stock next time. Added some sirracha in addition to hot sauce and seasoning. Finally, used 15 oz. can of diced tomatoes instead of fresh.
Absolutely delicious. I was hesitant to make because of the roux, but it was well worth it. I will definitely be making this again. Only substitution was I used butter instead of the vegetable oil.

I made quite a few changeI added okra, chicken, chicken broth (because thats what i had, and my ragin' cajun all purpose cajun seasoning. I might have went a little overboard with my spices but im pleased enough with the results. Not my daddys cookin though! Ill keep trying.

I made this last night, and it was delicious! After reading the reviews, I made a few adjustments. I used a mixture of bacon grease and butter instead of the oil, and reduced the amount to 1/4 c. I used 1/2 can of petite diced tomatoes. I used 1/2 Old Bay and 1/2 Tony Chatcheries for the seafood seasoning (and reduced the amount to taste). I used frozen crawfish tails (thawed and rinsed). I simmered the veggies a little longer to soften. Next time I'd like to try adding some andouille or Conecuh sausage, and maybe will add some corn kernels.
